body:
you would have to show how what you are doing is different. Is there a reason you are using 32-bit at all? 

pls show ``pd.show_versions()``
```
In [4]: !cat test.csv
a,b,c
1,2,3
4,5,6

In [5]: !ls -ltr *.csv
-rw-r--r--  1 jreback  staff  18 Dec 23 16:39 test.csv

In [6]: !pwd
/Users/jreback/pandas

In [7]: pd.read_csv('/Users/jreback/pandas/test.csv')
Out[7]: 
   a  b  c
0  1  2  3
1  4  5  6
```

I have to use 32 bit system, because I am working on a virtual machine, and my DOS does not allow 64-bit linux installation. I cannot change it.

Output of pd.show_versions():
```
INSTALLED VERSIONS
------------------
commit: None
python: 3.6.3.final.0
python-bits: 32
OS: Linux
OS-release: 4.10.0-42-generic
machine: i686
processor: i686
byteorder: little
LC_ALL: None
LANG: en_US.UTF-8
LOCALE: en_US.UTF-8

pandas: 0.21.1
pytest: 3.3.0
pip: 9.0.1
setuptools: 36.5.0.post20170920
Cython: 0.27.3
numpy: 1.13.3
scipy: 1.0.0
pyarrow: None
xarray: None
IPython: 6.2.1
sphinx: 1.6.3
patsy: 0.4.1

pytz: 2017.3
blosc: None

tables: 3.3.0
numexpr: 2.6.4
feather: None

openpyxl: 2.4.9

bs4: 4.6.0
html5lib: 1.0.1
sqlalchemy: 1.1.13
pymysql: None
psycopg2: None
jinja2: 2.10
s3fs: None
fastparquet: None
pandas_gbq: None
pandas_datareader: None
```

@mknorps, could you please run the following piece of code on your machine and see if it throws "Illegal instruction" too? (that's the case for me)

```
import numpy as np

a = np.arange(0, 100, 1)
np.where(a>90)
```
If yes, then we could narrow down the issue to https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/9532 and other issues related to AVX2 support detection. If not, what do you see if you run:

```gdb -ex r --args python project.py```

(you will need to install gdb first)

@krassowski bingo! thank you
I got the same issue with np.where(a>90).
I think that this issue is solved in the newest version of numpy.
Also, I created a clean virtual environment with numpy and pandas only.

With following setup all works fine:
```
>>> pd.show_versions()

INSTALLED VERSIONS
------------------
commit: None
python: 3.6.3.final.0
python-bits: 32
OS: Linux

```

Unfortunately still not fine. When I run the same pandas & numpy setup on virtual machine with Python 2.5.2 the error appeared again.
I created a test file test.py with code from @krassowski and debugging gives me:
```
(venv) knorpma1@knorpma1-VirtualBox:~/Documents/DATA_projects$ gdb -ex r --args python test.py
GNU gdb (Ubuntu 7.11.1-0ubuntu1~16.5) 7.11.1

[Thread debugging using libthread_db enabled]
Using host libthread_db library "/lib/i386-linux-gnu/libthread_db.so.1".

Program received signal SIGILL, Illegal instruction.
0xb5f87218 in LONG_greater_avx2 (args=args@entry=0xbfffe54c, dimensions=dimensions@entry=0xbfffe558, steps=steps@entry=0xbfffe564, 
    __NPY_UNUSED_TAGGEDfunc=__NPY_UNUSED_TAGGEDfunc@entry=0x0) at numpy/core/src/umath/loops.c.src:936
936	numpy/core/src/umath/loops.c.src: No such file or directory.

```
